The creators of OSSU i hope that this request find you well.

**What is the problem of math education in general and how OSSU could contribute to fix this problem ?**

OSSU is providing a learning opportunity for everyone who wants to learn Computer Science given that they've the time and effort required to pursue the studies [^1]. This means democratizing Computer Science education; make it accessible to everyone. Accessibility doesn't mean only providing the required material (i.e. courses) for free, but also providing the road-map and guidance on certain issues that the beginner learner doesn't have the experience to know or consider. And this is what OSSU is achieving by providing the courses, the road-map and the mentoring in the form of detailed guidance [^2]. 

Computer Science as a discipline is a branch of mathematics. Most universities around the world assume that students who aim at studying Computer Science have finished high school Mathematics. The way mathematics is taught in high school is not the best way to teach it. In fact, i don't think that anyone knows what is the best way to teach it. Nonetheless it remains a fact that many students who hate mathematics - because of a bad teacher, or the subject is presented in a way that doesn't reflect the true nature of Mathematics - are not in fact bad at Mathematics. This means that if the way Mathematics is presented in high schools changed, many'll find it an appealing and natural subject to learn [^3]; they'll become good at it. Changing the way Mathematics is presented in High Schools means introducing Mathematics when needed, not as a bunch of facts and techniques that the student should master; but as a tool for interpreting, solving, and expressing problems. In short, introduce Mathematics in relation to some problem, in the light of, or in context of something related to the field you study - which is CS in our case.

Given the above, and given the good intention of OSSU creators to advance humanity by making Computer Science learning accessible to a greater number of people who're willing to put their time and effort to become Computer Scientists, I claim that there is an opportunity for OSSU to fix a problem related to teaching mathematics in formal education, and hence make the curriculum accessible to a greater number of people, some of which can become good at CS and Math but discouraged by the mathematics - the problem of teaching math as a bunch of facts or techniques produced by some people (i.e. mathematicians) that the students ought to master - by introducing math lately in the curriculum. 

**How this proposed solution will contribute to fixing the math teaching problem in formal education ?**

By the time the learner finish "Intro CS" they would've been introduced to some mathematical concepts but in a superficial way. They'd also have an answer to the question: Is CS my field of interest or not. This is in fact the function of an Intro Course; to give the learner enough knowledge in order to decide if they would like to purse more or that what they've known is enough.

From the three courses in "Intro cs" -  CS50P, Python for Everybody, 6.0001 Introduction to Computer Science and Programming in Python - 6.0001 is the only course that introduce mathematical concepts because it's the only course that introduces CS. The other two courses are programming and not CS courses. 

For instance, in 6.0001 the first appearance of mathematical concept is in "Lec-3" the cubic root of some number and the "guess and check method"; The second appearance in "Lec-10,11" in the form of graphs of the running time of algorithms - constant, linear, log, ...etc. None of these require a whole knowledge and mastering of High School Math; they just need a simple search on google to understand what it means by cubic root. In terms of the graphs, the function of graphs in Mathematics in general is to express some Mathematical ideas visually. So, by only looking to the graphs the learner could see what constant mean visually and so on, also something that doesn't require mastering High School Math.

MIT, the university that is issuing the course is an engineering university. In fact the Bachelor Degree of Computer Science at MIT is a Degree in Computer Science and Engineering [^4]. Hence, MIT assumes that their freshman students should have High School knowledge not only of math but of physics also. This is one of the reasons of why MIT is known for its hard admission exams and the way they filter their freshmen students.

Every higher education institution has a way to filter students through entrance examinations - SAT, MCAT, ...etc. The reason that this is the case in higher education is because every college and university have a finite number of places for students - a situation which online MOOC education doesn't face - and the growth in higher education made an intense competition for seats [^5]. Therefore, filtering out students doesn't have any meaning in MOOC settings. In fact the opposite is true. MOOC is intended to everyone that is willing to invest their effort and time regardless of their background. Even if they didn't attend High School all together.

6.0001 Course itself - Not MIT, The University - doesn't require High School math as a prerequisite [^6]. The text-book recommended by the course itself is a book by Professor John Guttag, in the preface of the book there is no mentions to any prerequisite. In fact Professor John said "The book is aimed at 1) readers with little or no prior programming experience who have a desire to understand computational approaches to problem solving, and 2) more experienced programmers who want to learn how to use computation to model things or explore data." This second target audience of the book "The experienced programmers" are required to know, in Prof. John words "[what is required is] no knowledge of mathematics beyond high school algebra, but do assume that the reader is comfortable with rigorous thinking and is not intimidated by mathematical concepts." This requirement is needed for "experienced programmers" taking a second course in computer science, which is 6.0002, a course not in OSSU curriculum, and is not an introductory course. Professor John's book contains the material for teaching 6.0001 & 6.0002 [^7].  MIT in another place recommended prerequisite for this course 6.0001, which is in their words "No prior programming experience is necessary to take, understand, or be successful in 6.0001. Familiarity with pre-calculus, especially series, will be helpful for some topics, but is not required to understand the majority of the content. [^8]" The keywords here is "Some Topics" and "Is not required to understand the majority of the content". Does this means that MIT recommended pre-calculus and hence High School math as prerequisite for 6.0001 ? Yes. Does this mean that their is no other way to learn 6.0001 than learning the entirety of High School math ? No, because MIT themselves put this phrase "Is not required to understand the majority of the content" for a reason, to say, don't get discouraged to take this course if you don't have pre-calculus and hence High School math because "[its] not required to understand the majority of content". Is it then necessary to not take 6.0001 course until finishing High School Mathematics ? My answer is no. You can take the course and google the two concepts that will meet you.


**What can be modified in the current OSSU Curriculum ?**

I propose to move Mathematics Prerequisite to later in the Curriculum, to either directly before Core Programming, or to Directly before Core Mathematics. None of the Core Programming courses in fact require any Mathematics as a prerequisite. And prerequisites on Courcera, and in every other online learning platform or course, has to be said explicitly. 

In fact the reason to take High School mathematics is because it's a prerequisite for calculus. But than we must ask why we learn calculus in Computer Science, or at least why before Discrete Math ? Some would answer, because Calculus is a prerequisite for Discrete Math. This is what MIT recommended, but again, MIT is engineering university with an intense competition for the number of students allowed to study at MIT. 

This whole organization of Mathematics Curriculum in USA, and by implication in most of the world is questionable. Arithmetic, then Geometry, then Pre-Algebra, then High School Math (Pre-calculus), then calculus and discrete mathematics, is not the only why to learn mathematics; most of the people can learn Mathematics to even Higher Mathematics (Graduate level Mathematics) starting from Discrete Math or what we call "Math for Computer Science"[^9]. However, this argument is not the scope of this discussion. I just put it forward for the sake of showing that what we take for granted about learning math is not necessary the best way to learn it. this is not my personal opinion, this is the opinion of many great mathematician, for instance, George Pólya, and The Mathematician and Philosopher, Imre Lakatos ([^3] for more details).

**Final Words**

I'll Finish with a quote from the philosopher, educator, encyclopedist, and popular author Mortimer J. Adler that i think is directed to anyone who is responsible for providing education for people especially MOOC education. 
"We are on record as holding that unlimited education opportunity-or, specking practically, education opportunity that is limited only by individual desire, ability, and need- is the most valuable service that society can provide for its members. That we don't know how to provide that kind of opportunity is no reason to give up the attempt.[^10]."

So, by only looking to the graphs the learner could see what constant mean visually and so on, also something that doesn't require mastering High School Math.

MIT, the university that is issuing the course is an engineering university. In fact the Bachelor Degree of Computer Science at MIT is a Degree in Computer Science and Engineering [^4]. Hence, MIT assumes that their freshman students should have High School knowledge not only of math but of physics also. This is one of the reasons of why MIT is known for its hard admission exams and the way they filter their freshmen students.

Every higher education institution has a way to filter students through entrance examinations - SAT, MCAT, ...etc. The reason that this is the case in higher education is because every college and university have a finite number of places for students - a situation which online MOOC education doesn't face - and the growth in higher education made an intense competition for seats [^5]. Therefore, filtering out students doesn't have any meaning in MOOC settings. In fact the opposite is true. MOOC is intended to everyone that is willing to invest their effort and time regardless of their background. Even if they didn't attend High School all together.

6.0001 Course itself - Not MIT, The University - doesn't require High School math as a prerequisite [^6]. The text-book recommended by the course itself is a book by Professor John Guttag, in the preface of the book there is no mentions to any prerequisite. In fact Professor John said "The book is aimed at 1) readers with little or no prior programming experience who have a desire to understand computational approaches to problem solving, and 2) more experienced programmers who want to learn how to use computation to model things or explore data." This second target audience of the book "The experienced programmers" are required to know, in Prof. John words "[what is required is] no knowledge of mathematics beyond high school algebra, but do assume that the reader is comfortable with rigorous thinking and is not intimidated by mathematical concepts." This requirement is needed for "experienced programmers" taking a second course in computer science, which is 6.0002, a course not in OSSU curriculum, and is not an introductory course. Professor John's book contains the material for teaching 6.0001 & 6.0002 [^7].  MIT in another place recommended prerequisite for this course 6.0001, which is in their words "No prior programming experience is necessary to take, understand, or be successful in 6.0001. Familiarity with pre-calculus, especially series, will be helpful for some topics, but is not required to understand the majority of the content. [^8]" The keywords here is "Some Topics" and "Is not required to understand the majority of the content". Does this means that MIT recommended pre-calculus and hence High School math as prerequisite for 6.0001 ? Yes. Does this mean that their is no other way to learn 6.0001 than learning the entirety of High School math ? No, because MIT themselves put this phrase "Is not required to understand the majority of the content" for a reason, to say, don't get discouraged to take this course if you don't have pre-calculus and hence High School math because "[its] not required to understand the majority of content". Is it then necessary to not take 6.0001 course until finishing High School Mathematics ? My answer is no. You can take the course and google the two concepts that will meet you.


**What can be modified in the current OSSU Curriculum ?**

I propose to move Mathematics Prerequisite to later in the Curriculum, to either directly before Core Programming, or to Directly before Core Mathematics. None of the Core Programming courses in fact require any Mathematics as a prerequisite. And prerequisites on Courcera, and in every other online learning platform or course, has to be said explicitly. 

In fact the reason to take High School mathematics is because it's a prerequisite for calculus. But than we must ask why we learn calculus in Computer Science, or at least why before Discrete Math ? Some would answer, because Calculus is a prerequisite for Discrete Math. This is what MIT recommended, but again, MIT is engineering university with an intense competition for the number of students allowed to study at MIT. 

This whole organization of Mathematics Curriculum in USA, and by implication in most of the world is questionable. Arithmetic, then Geometry, then Pre-Algebra, then High School Math (Pre-calculus), then calculus and discrete mathematics, is not the only why to learn mathematics; most of the people can learn Mathematics to even Higher Mathematics (Graduate level Mathematics) starting from Discrete Math or what we call "Math for Computer Science"[^9]. However, this argument is not the scope of this discussion. I just put it forward for the sake of showing that what we take for granted about learning math is not necessary the best way to learn it. this is not my personal opinion, this is the opinion of many great mathematician, for instance, George Pólya, and The Mathematician and Philosopher, Imre Lakatos ([^3] for more details).

**Final Words**

I'll Finish with a quote from the philosopher, educator, encyclopedist, and popular author Mortimer J. Adler that i think is directed to anyone who is responsible for providing education for people especially MOOC education. 
"We are on record as holding that unlimited education opportunity-or, specking practically, education opportunity that is limited only by individual desire, ability, and need- is the most valuable service that society can provide for its members. That we don't know how to provide that kind of opportunity is no reason to give up the attempt.[^10]."

I think it safe to assume that MIT requires you to have a good understanding of high school algebra before you take the course.

MIT recommended High School math as a prerequisite for this course in the link you provided of edx. But on the other link they didn't recommended. (https://ocw.mit.edu/courses/6-0001-introduction-to-computer-science-and-programming-in-python-fall-2016/).  Don't forget that at MIT Computer Science degree means Computer Science and Electrical Engineering degree.

In another link of MIT they say. 
> Prerequisites: No prior programming experience is necessary to take, understand, or be successful in 6.0001. Familiarity with pre-calculus, especially series, will be helpful for some topics, but is not required to understand the majority of the content.

"But is not required to understand the majority of the content" its required to understand "some topics". They put this sentence for a reason. They want to say if you don't have a familiarity with Pre-calculus - which is trig & algebra - don't get discouraged because you'll understand "the majority of content". In fact anyone who took this course knows that you can master it without the need to master High School Math. (https://mitocw.ups.edu.ec/courses/intro-programming/).

Does this means that High School Math is unimportant ?
Not at all. It just means you can delay it and take it after you've finished this course or even later. The learner will learn a lot of math in Computer Science. My point is not to make Math an obstacle. Encourage the learner to love the discipline first, and then present them with all the math that's required. This is my whole point.

The creators of OSSU i hope that this request find you well.

**What is the problem of math education in general and how OSSU could contribute to fix this problem ?**

OSSU is providing a learning opportunity for everyone who wants to learn Computer Science given that they've the time and effort required to pursue the studies [^1]. This means democratizing Computer Science education; make it accessible to everyone. Accessibility doesn't mean only providing the required material (i.e. courses) for free, but also providing the road-map and guidance on certain issues that the beginner learner doesn't have the experience to know or consider. And this is what OSSU is achieving by providing the courses, the road-map and the mentoring in the form of detailed guidance [^2]. 

Computer Science as a discipline is a branch of mathematics. Most universities around the world assume that students who aim at studying Computer Science have finished high school Mathematics. The way mathematics is taught in high school is not the best way to teach it. In fact, i don't think that anyone knows what is the best way to teach it. Nonetheless it remains a fact that many students who hate mathematics - because of a bad teacher, or the subject is presented in a way that doesn't reflect the true nature of Mathematics - are not in fact bad at Mathematics. This means that if the way Mathematics is presented in high schools changed, many'll find it an appealing and natural subject to learn [^3]; they'll become good at it. Changing the way Mathematics is presented in High Schools means introducing Mathematics when needed, not as a bunch of facts and techniques that the student should master; but as a tool for interpreting, solving, and expressing problems. In short, introduce Mathematics in relation to some problem, in the light of, or in context of something related to the field you study - which is CS in our case.

Given the above, and given the good intention of OSSU creators to advance humanity by making Computer Science learning accessible to a greater number of people who're willing to put their time and effort to become Computer Scientists, I claim that there is an opportunity for OSSU to fix a problem related to teaching mathematics in formal education, and hence make the curriculum accessible to a greater number of people, some of which can become good at CS and Math but discouraged by the mathematics - the problem of teaching math as a bunch of facts or techniques produced by some people (i.e. mathematicians) that the students ought to master - by introducing math lately in the curriculum. 

**How this proposed solution will contribute to fixing the math teaching problem in formal education ?**

By the time the learner finish "Intro CS" they would've been introduced to some mathematical concepts but in a superficial way. They'd also have an answer to the question: Is CS my field of interest or not. This is in fact the function of an Intro Course; to give the learner enough knowledge in order to decide if they would like to purse more or that what they've known is enough.

From the three courses in "Intro cs" -  CS50P, Python for Everybody, 6.0001 Introduction to Computer Science and Programming in Python - 6.0001 is the only course that introduce mathematical concepts because it's the only course that introduces CS. The other two courses are programming and not CS courses. 

For instance, in 6.0001 the first appearance of mathematical concept is in "Lec-3" the cubic root of some number and the "guess and check method"; The second appearance in "Lec-10,11" in the form of graphs of the running time of algorithms - constant, linear, log, ...etc. None of these require a whole knowledge and mastering of High School Math; they just need a simple search on google to understand what it means by cubic root. In terms of the graphs, the function of graphs in Mathematics in general is to express some Mathematical ideas visually. So, by only looking to the graphs the learner could see what constant mean visually and so on, also something that doesn't require mastering High School Math.

MIT, the university that is issuing the course is an engineering university. In fact the Bachelor Degree of Computer Science at MIT is a Degree in Computer Science and Engineering [^4]. Hence, MIT assumes that their freshman students should have High School knowledge not only of math but of physics also. This is one of the reasons of why MIT is known for its hard admission exams and the way they filter their freshmen students.

In fact Professor John said "The book is aimed at 1) readers with little or no prior programming experience who have a desire to understand computational approaches to problem solving, and 2) more experienced programmers who want to learn how to use computation to model things or explore data." This second target audience of the book "The experienced programmers" are required to know, in Prof. John words "[what is required is] no knowledge of mathematics beyond high school algebra, but do assume that the reader is comfortable with rigorous thinking and is not intimidated by mathematical concepts." This requirement is needed for "experienced programmers" taking a second course in computer science, which is 6.0002, a course not in OSSU curriculum, and is not an introductory course. Professor John's book contains the material for teaching 6.0001 & 6.0002 [^7].  MIT in another place recommended prerequisite for this course 6.0001, which is in their words "No prior programming experience is necessary to take, understand, or be successful in 6.0001. Familiarity with pre-calculus, especially series, will be helpful for some topics, but is not required to understand the majority of the content. [^8]" The keywords here is "Some Topics" and "Is not required to understand the majority of the content". Does this means that MIT recommended pre-calculus and hence High School math as prerequisite for 6.0001 ? Yes. Does this mean that their is no other way to learn 6.0001 than learning the entirety of High School math ? No, because MIT themselves put this phrase "Is not required to understand the majority of the content" for a reason, to say, don't get discouraged to take this course if you don't have pre-calculus and hence High School math because "[its] not required to understand the majority of content". Is it then necessary to not take 6.0001 course until finishing High School Mathematics ? My answer is no. You can take the course and google the two concepts that will meet you.


**What can be modified in the current OSSU Curriculum ?**

I propose to move Mathematics Prerequisite to later in the Curriculum, to either directly before Core Programming, or to Directly before Core Mathematics. None of the Core Programming courses in fact require any Mathematics as a prerequisite. And prerequisites on Courcera, and in every other online learning platform or course, has to be said explicitly. 

In fact the reason to take High School mathematics is because it's a prerequisite for calculus. But than we must ask why we learn calculus in Computer Science, or at least why before Discrete Math ? Some would answer, because Calculus is a prerequisite for Discrete Math. This is what MIT recommended, but again, MIT is engineering university with an intense competition for the number of students allowed to study at MIT. 

This whole organization of Mathematics Curriculum in USA, and by implication in most of the world is questionable. Arithmetic, then Geometry, then Pre-Algebra, then High School Math (Pre-calculus), then calculus and discrete mathematics, is not the only why to learn mathematics; most of the people can learn Mathematics to even Higher Mathematics (Graduate level Mathematics) starting from Discrete Math or what we call "Math for Computer Science"[^9]. However, this argument is not the scope of this discussion. I just put it forward for the sake of showing that what we take for granted about learning math is not necessary the best way to learn it. this is not my personal opinion, this is the opinion of many great mathematician, for instance, George Pólya, and The Mathematician and Philosopher, Imre Lakatos ([^3] for more details).

**Final Words**

I'll Finish with a quote from the philosopher, educator, encyclopedist, and popular author Mortimer J. Adler that i think is directed to anyone who is responsible for providing education for people especially MOOC education.

False}, 'created_at': '2024-04-05T05:48:53Z', 'updated_at': '2024-04-05T05:48:53Z', 'author_association': 'NONE', 'body': 'I want to interject to say that the knowledge in prerequisites math is required in the edX version, as you can read here: https://www.edx.org/learn/computer-science/massachusetts-institute-of-technology-introduction-to-computer-science-and-programming-using-python

> **Prerequisites:** High school algebra and a reasonable aptitude for mathematics. Students without prior programming background will find there is a steep learning curve and may have to put in more than the estimated time effort.

The course adds that, in addition to prerequisite math, you also need to have a fairly good grasp on mathematical problem solving. I hope this message finds you well. I am writing to propose the addition of an Arabic translation to the OSSU Computer Science Curriculum. Currently, the curriculum is available in English, Chinese, and Brazilian Portuguese, and I am eager to contribute by creating an Arabic version.

_**Issue Title: Adding Arabic Translation to OSSU Computer Science Curriculum**_

_**Issue Body:**_

I am enthusiastic about volunteering to translate the OSSU Computer Science Curriculum into Arabic. With over 400 million Arabic speakers worldwide, this translation has the potential to benefit a significant number of learners who prefer Arabic as their primary learning language.

I am committed to actively participating in the translation process, ensuring that the content is not only accurately translated but also culturally relevant. This initiative aligns with the OSSU's goal of making quality education accessible to a global audience.

Please let me know if there are specific guidelines or requirements for translations, and if there are any existing resources or tools that I should use during the translation process.

I look forward to contributing to this fantastic initiative and helping make the OSSU Computer Science Curriculum available to Arabic-speaking learners.

Thank you for considering my proposal.

Best regards, Bassam Mejlaoui @mejbass ", 'reactions': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/ossu/computer-science/issues/1214/reactions', 'total_count': 1, '+1': 0, '-1': 0, 'laugh': 0, 'hooray': 0, 'confused': 0, 'heart': 1, 'rocket': 0, 'eyes': 0}, 'timeline_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/ossu/computer-science/issues/1214/timeline', 'performed_via_github_app': None, 'state_reason': None}, 'comment': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/ossu/computer-science/issues/comments/2038930184', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/ossu/computer-science/issues/1214#issuecomment-2038930184', 'issue_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/ossu/computer-science/issues/1214', 'id': 2038930184, 'node_id': 'IC_kwDOAShAGM55h5sI', 'user': {'login': 'waciumawanjohi', 'id': 18407643, 'node_id': 'MDQ6VXNlcjE4NDA3NjQz', 'avatar_url': 'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/18407643?v=4', 'gravatar_id': '', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/users/waciumawanjohi', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/waciumawanjohi', 'followers_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/waciumawanjohi/followers', 'following_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/waciumawanjohi/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/waciumawanjohi/gists{/gist_id}', 'starred_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/waciumawanjohi/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'subscriptions_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/waciumawanjohi/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/waciumawanjohi/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/waciumawanjohi/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/waciumawanjohi/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/waciumawanjohi/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}, 'created_at': '2024-04-05T04:54:25Z', 'updated_at': '2024-04-05T04:54:25Z', 'author_association': 'MEMBER', 'body': "The curricular guide you have written is a fine introduction (or guide) to the proposed curriculum. {'action': 'created', 'issue': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/ossu/computer-science/issues/1231', 'repository_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/ossu/computer-science', 'labels_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/ossu/computer-science/issues/1231/labels{/name}', 'comments_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/ossu/computer-science/issues/1231/comments', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/ossu/computer-science/issues/1231/events', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/ossu/computer-science/issues/1231', 'id': 2224794472, 'node_id': 'I_kwDOAShAGM6Em6to', 'number': 1231, 'title': 'A proposal to shift the High School Matheamtics to later in the Curriculum. ', 'user': {'login': 'BurzumBlack', 'id': 50082799, 'node_id': 'MDQ6VXNlcjUwMDgyNzk5', 'avatar_url': 'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/50082799?v=4', 'gravatar_id': '', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/users/BurzumBlack', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/BurzumBlack', 'followers_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/BurzumBlack/followers', 'following_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/BurzumBlack/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/BurzumBlack/gists{/gist_id}', 'starred_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/BurzumBlack/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'subscriptions_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/BurzumBlack/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/BurzumBlack/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/BurzumBlack/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/BurzumBlack/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/BurzumBlack/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}, 'labels': [], 'state': 'open', 'locked': False, 'assignee': None, 'assignees': [], 'milestone': None, 'comments': 3, 'created_at': '2024-04-04T08:14:19Z', 'updated_at': '2024-04-05T03:58:35Z', 'closed_at': None, 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': 'TLTR;

The creators of OSSU i hope that this request find you well.

**What is the problem of math education in general and how OSSU could contribute to fix this problem ?**

OSSU is providing a learning opportunity for everyone who wants to learn Computer Science given that they've the time and effort required to pursue the studies [^1]. This means democratizing Computer Science education; make it accessible to everyone. Accessibility doesn't mean only providing the required material (i.e. courses) for free, but also providing the road-map and guidance on certain issues that the beginner learner doesn't have the experience to know or consider. And this is what OSSU is achieving by providing the courses, the road-map and the mentoring in the form of detailed guidance [^2]. 

Computer Science as a discipline is a branch of mathematics. Most universities around the world assume that students who aim at studying Computer Science have finished high school Mathematics. The way mathematics is taught in high school is not the best way to teach it. In fact, i don't think that anyone knows what is the best way to teach it. Nonetheless it remains a fact that many students who hate mathematics - because of a bad teacher, or the subject is presented in a way that doesn't reflect the true nature of Mathematics - are not in fact bad at Mathematics. This means that if the way Mathematics is presented in high schools changed, many'll find it an appealing and natural subject to learn [^3]; they'll become good at it. Changing the way Mathematics is presented in High Schools means introducing Mathematics when needed, not as a bunch of facts and techniques that the student should master; but as a tool for interpreting, solving, and expressing problems. In short, introduce Mathematics in relation to some problem, in the light of, or in context of something related to the field you study - which is CS in our case.

Given the above, and given the good intention of OSSU creators to advance humanity by making Computer Science learning accessible to a greater number of people who're willing to put their time and effort to become Computer Scientists, I claim that there is an opportunity for OSSU to fix a problem related to teaching mathematics in formal education, and hence make the curriculum accessible to a greater number of people, some of which can become good at CS and Math but discouraged by the mathematics - the problem of teaching math as a bunch of facts or techniques produced by some people (i.e. mathematicians) that the students ought to master - by introducing math lately in the curriculum. 

**How this proposed solution will contribute to fixing the math teaching problem in formal education ?**

By the time the learner finish "Intro CS" they would've been introduced to some mathematical concepts but in a superficial way. They'd also have an answer to the question: Is CS my field of interest or not. This is in fact the function of an Intro Course; to give the learner enough knowledge in order to decide if they would like to purse more or that what they've known is enough.

From the three courses in "Intro cs" -  CS50P, Python for Everybody, 6.0001 Introduction to Computer Science and Programming in Python - 6.0001 is the only course that introduce mathematical concepts because it's the only course that introduces CS. The other two courses are programming and not CS courses. 

For instance, in 6.0001 the first appearance of mathematical concept is in "Lec-3" the cubic root of some number and the "guess and check method"; The second appearance in "Lec-10,11" in the form of graphs of the running time of algorithms - constant, linear, log, ...etc. None of these require a whole knowledge and mastering of High School Math; they just need a simple search on google to understand what it means by cubic root. In terms of the graphs, the function of graphs in Mathematics in general is to express some Mathematical ideas visually. So, by only looking to the graphs the learner could see what constant mean visually and so on, also something that doesn't require mastering High School Math.

MIT, the university that is issuing the course is an engineering university. In fact the Bachelor Degree of Computer Science at MIT is a Degree in Computer Science and Engineering [^4]. Hence, MIT assumes that their freshman students should have High School knowledge not only of math but of physics also. This is one of the reasons of why MIT is known for its hard admission exams and the way they filter their freshmen students.

Every higher education institution has a way to filter students through entrance examinations - SAT, MCAT, ...etc. The reason that this is the case in higher education is because every college and university have a finite number of places for students - a situation which online MOOC education doesn't face - and the growth in higher education made an intense competition for seats [^5]. Therefore, filtering out students doesn't have any meaning in MOOC settings. In fact the opposite is true. MOOC is intended to everyone that is willing to invest their effort and time regardless of their background. Even if they didn't attend High School all together.

6.0001 Course itself - Not MIT, The University - doesn't require High School math as a prerequisite [^6]. The text-book recommended by the course itself is a book by Professor John Guttag, in the preface of the book there is no mentions to any prerequisite. In fact Professor John said "The book is aimed at 1) readers with little or no prior programming experience who have a desire to understand computational approaches to problem solving, and 2) more experienced programmers who want to learn how to use computation to model things or explore data." This second target audience of the book "The experienced programmers" are required to know, in Prof. John words "[what is required is] no knowledge of mathematics beyond high school algebra, but do assume that the reader is comfortable with rigorous thinking and is not intimidated by mathematical concepts." This requirement is needed for "experienced programmers" taking a second course in computer science, which is 6.0002, a course not in OSSU curriculum, and is not an introductory course. Professor John's book contains the material for teaching 6.0001 & 6.0002 [^7].  MIT in another place recommended prerequisite for this course 6.0001, which is in their words "No prior programming experience is necessary to take, understand, or be successful in 6.0001. Familiarity with pre-calculus, especially series, will be helpful for some topics, but is not required to understand the majority of the content. [^8]" The keywords here is "Some Topics" and "Is not required to understand the majority of the content". Does this means that MIT recommended pre-calculus and hence High School math as prerequisite for 6.0001 ? Yes. Does this mean that their is no other way to learn 6.0001 than learning the entirety of High School math ? No, because MIT themselves put this phrase "Is not required to understand the majority of the content" for a reason, to say, don't get discouraged to take this course if you don't have pre-calculus and hence High School math because "[its] not required to understand the majority of content". Is it then necessary to not take 6.0001 course until finishing High School Mathematics ? My answer is no. You can take the course and google the two concepts that will meet you.


**What can be modified in the current OSSU Curriculum ?**

I propose to move Mathematics Prerequisite to later in the Curriculum, to either directly before Core Programming, or to Directly before Core Mathematics. None of the Core Programming courses in fact require any Mathematics as a prerequisite. And prerequisites on Courcera, and in every other online learning platform or course, has to be said explicitly. 

In fact the reason to take High School mathematics is because it's a prerequisite for calculus. But than we must ask why we learn calculus in Computer Science, or at least why before Discrete Math ? Some would answer, because Calculus is a prerequisite for Discrete Math. This is what MIT recommended, but again, MIT is engineering university with an intense competition for the number of students allowed to study at MIT. 

This whole organization of Mathematics Curriculum in USA, and by implication in most of the world is questionable. Arithmetic, then Geometry, then Pre-Algebra, then High School Math (Pre-calculus), then calculus and discrete mathematics, is not the only why to learn mathematics; most of the people can learn Mathematics to even Higher Mathematics (Graduate level Mathematics) starting from Discrete Math or what we call "Math for Computer Science"[^9]. However, this argument is not the scope of this discussion. I just put it forward for the sake of showing that what we take for granted about learning math is not necessary the best way to learn it. this is not my personal opinion, this is the opinion of many great mathematician, for instance, George Pólya, and The Mathematician and Philosopher, Imre Lakatos ([^3] for more details).

**Final Words**

I'll Finish with a quote from the philosopher, educator, encyclopedist, and popular author Mortimer J. Adler that i think is directed to anyone who is responsible for providing education for people especially MOOC education. 
"We are on record as holding that unlimited education opportunity-or, specking practically, education opportunity that is limited only by individual desire, ability, and need- is the most valuable service that society can provide for its members. That we don't know how to provide that kind of opportunity is no reason to give up the attempt.[^10]."

I hope this message finds you well. I am writing to propose the addition of an Arabic translation to the OSSU Computer Science Curriculum. Currently, the curriculum is available in English, Chinese, and Brazilian Portuguese, and I am eager to contribute by creating an Arabic version.

_**Issue Title: Adding Arabic Translation to OSSU Computer Science Curriculum**_

_**Issue Body:**_

I am enthusiastic about volunteering to translate the OSSU Computer Science Curriculum into Arabic. With over 400 million Arabic speakers worldwide, this translation has the potential to benefit a significant number of learners who prefer Arabic as their primary learning language.

I am committed to actively participating in the translation process, ensuring that the content is not only accurately translated but also culturally relevant. This initiative aligns with the OSSU's goal of making quality education accessible to a global audience.

Please let me know if there are specific guidelines or requirements for translations, and if there are any existing resources or tools that I should use during the translation process.

I look forward to contributing to this fantastic initiative and helping make the OSSU Computer Science Curriculum available to Arabic-speaking learners.

Thank you for considering my proposal.

Certainly! Here are the contributions policy and a clear explanation of the curricular guide for the Arabic OSSU Computer Science Curriculum:


### Contribution Policy for OSSU Computer Science Curriculum

#### Introduction
At OSSU (Open Source Society University), we welcome contributions from individuals passionate about advancing computer science education. This policy outlines guidelines and procedures for contributing to our curriculum.

#### Guidelines for Contribution
1. **Alignment with Objectives**: Contributions should align with the objectives and structure of the OSSU Computer Science Curriculum.
  
2. **Relevance and Quality**: Ensure contributions are relevant to computer science education and of high quality.

3. **Openness and Accessibility**: Contributions must be openly accessible and available for enrollment by learners.

4. **Adherence to Standards**: Contributions should adhere to the curricular standards outlined in the CS 2013: Curriculum Guidelines for Undergraduate Degree Programs in Computer Science.

5. **Review Process**: All contributions undergo a review process by the OSSU team to ensure quality and alignment.

6. **Licensing**: Contributors must have necessary rights and specify the appropriate license for contributed content.

7. **Respect for Code of Conduct**: Adhere to the OSSU code of conduct and promote a positive learning environment.

#### Contribution Process
1. **Submission**: Submit contributions via GitHub pull requests to the relevant repository in the OSSU organization.

2. **Review**: The OSSU team reviews contributions, providing feedback if necessary.

3. **Approval**: Approved contributions are merged into the curriculum repository.

4. **Acknowledgment**: Contributors are acknowledged for their contributions.

5. **Continuous Improvement**: Contributions are subject to ongoing review and improvement.

#### Conclusion
By adhering to these guidelines, individuals can contribute to enhancing the OSSU Computer Science Curriculum, empowering learners worldwide.

### سياسة المساهمة في منهج علم الحاسوب لدى OSSU

#### المقدمة
في OSSU (Open Source Society University)، نرحب بالمساهمات من الأفراد الذين يشعرون بالحماسة لتقدم التعليم في مجال علوم الحاسوب. توضح هذه السياسة الإرشادات والإجراءات المتبعة للمساهمة في منهجنا.

#### الإرشادات للمساهمة
1. **موافقة على الأهداف**: يجب أن تتماشى المساهمات مع أهداف وهيكل منهج علوم الحاسوب لدى OSSU.

2. **الصلة والجودة**: تأكد من أن المساهمات ذات صلة بتعليم علوم الحاسوب وذات جودة عالية.

3. **الشفافية والوصولية**: يجب أن تكون المساهمات متاحة بشكل علني ومتاحة للتسجيل لدى المتعلمين.

4. **الالتزام بالمعايير**: يجب أن تلتزم المساهمات بالمعايير الفنية المحددة في CS 2013: Curriculum Guidelines for Undergraduate Degree Programs in Computer Science.

5. **عملية المراجعة**: تخضع جميع المساهمات لعملية مراجعة من قبل فريق OSSU لضمان الجودة والتوافق.

6. **الترخيص**: يجب على المساهمين أن يتمتعوا بالحقوق اللازمة وتحديد الترخيص المناسب للمحتوى المساهم به.

7. **احترام قواعد السلوك**: يتوقع من المساهمين الالتزام بقواعد السلوك لدى OSSU وتعزيز بيئة تعليمية إيجابية.

#### عملية المساهمة
1. **التقديم**: يمكن للمساهمين تقديم مساهماتهم عبر طلبات السحب في GitHub إلى المستودع المناسب في منظمة OSSU.

2. **المراجعة**: يقوم فريق OSSU بمراجعة المساهمات، وتقديم التعليقات إذا لزم الأمر.

3. **الموافقة**: بعد الموافقة، تُدمج المساهمات المعتمدة في مستودع المنهج.

4. **الاعتراف**: يتم الاعتراف بمساهمات المساهمين .

5. **التحسين المستمر**: تخضع المساهمات لمراجعة وتحسين مستمرين.

#### الخلاصة
من خلال الالتزام بهذه الإرشادات، يمكن للأفراد المساهمة في تحسين منهج علوم الحاسوب لدى OSSU، وتمكين المتعلمين في جميع أنحاء العالم.



---

### Explanation of OSSU Computer Science Curricular Guide

#### Overview
The OSSU Computer Science Curriculum offers a structured path for comprehensive education in computer science. It mirrors undergraduate degree requirements, excluding general education courses.

#### Structure
1. **Intro CS**: Provides an introduction to computer science for beginners.
  
2. **Core CS**: Covers essential topics such as programming, math, tools, systems, theory, security, applications, and ethics.

3. **Advanced CS**: Focuses on specialized topics allowing learners to delve deeper into areas of interest.

4. **Final Project**: Enables learners to apply knowledge and skills to solve real-world problems.

#### Duration and Flexibility
- Completion in approximately 2 years with consistent study efforts.
- Flexibility allows learners to progress at their own pace and choose elective courses based on interests.

#### Resources and Support
- All materials available online, with many courses offered for free.
- Support and guidance available through the OSSU community.

#### Recognition and Next Steps
- Upon completion, learners have acquired the equivalent of a full bachelor's degree in computer science.
- Encouraged to showcase accomplishments, seek job opportunities, continue learning, and contribute to the community.

#### Conclusion
The OSSU Computer Science Curriculum provides a structured and accessible path for individuals to obtain a comprehensive education in computer science. With emphasis on self-directed learning, flexibility, and community support, it empowers learners to pursue educational goals and advance careers in the field.

شرح دليل منهج العلوم الحاسوبية لدى OSSU
النظرة العامة
يقدم منهج علوم الحاسوب لدى OSSU مسارًا مُنظَّمًا للتعليم الشامل في علوم الحاسوب. يتماشى مع متطلبات الدرجة الجامعية الجامعية، باستثناء المقررات التعليمية العامة.

#### الهيكل
1. **مقدمة علوم الحاسوب: تقدم مقدمة في علوم الحاسوب للمبتدئين.**

2- **الأساسيات في علوم الحاسوب: تغطي مواضيع أساسية مثل البرمجة، والرياضيات، والأدوات، والأنظمة، والنظرية، والأمان، والتطبيقات، والأخلاقيات.**

3- **المستوى المتقدم في علوم الحاسوب: يركز على مواضيع متخصصة تسمح للمتعلمين بالتعمق في المجالات المهتمين بها.**

4- **المشروع النهائي: يمكن للمتعلمين تطبيق المعرفة والمهارات لحل المشكلات الحقيقية.**

#### المدة والمرونة
الانتهاء منه في حوالي سنتين مع جهود دراسية مستمرة.
المرونة تسمح للمتعلمين بالتقدم بمعدلهم الخاص واختيار المقررات الاختيارية بناءً على الاهتمامات.

#### الموارد والدعم
جميع المواد متاحة عبر الإنترنت، مع العديد من الدورات المجانية.
الدعم والإرشاد متاح من خلال مجتمع OSSU.

#### الخطوات التالية
عند الانتهاء، يكتسب المتعلمون ما يعادل درجة البكالوريوس الكاملة في علوم الحاسوب.
يُشجع على عرض الإنجازات، والبحث عن فرص العمل، ومواصلة التعلم، والمساهمة في المجتمع.

#### الخلاصة
يوفر منهج علوم الحاسوب لدى OSSU مسارًا منظمًا ومتاحًا للأفراد للحصول على تعليم شامل في علوم الحاسوب. بالتركيز على التعلم الذاتي، والمرونة، ودعم المجتمع، يمكنهم متابعة أهدافهم التعليمية وتطوير مساراتهم المهنية في هذا المجال.

', 'user': {'login': 'BurzumBlack', 'id': 50082799, 'node_id': 'MDQ6VXNlcjUwMDgyNzk5', 'avatar_url': 'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/50082799?v=4', 'gravatar_id': '', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/users/BurzumBlack', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/BurzumBlack', 'followers_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/BurzumBlack/followers', 'following_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/BurzumBlack/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/BurzumBlack/gists{/gist_id}', 'starred_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/BurzumBlack/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'subscriptions_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/BurzumBlack/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/BurzumBlack/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/BurzumBlack/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/BurzumBlack/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/BurzumBlack/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}, 'labels': [], 'state': 'open', 'locked': False, 'assignee': None, 'assignees': [], 'milestone': None, 'comments': 2, 'created_at': '2024-04-04T08:14:19Z', 'updated_at': '2024-04-04T12:26:18Z', 'closed_at': None, 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': 'TLTR;

The creators of OSSU i hope that this request find you well.

**What is the problem of math education in general and how OSSU could contribute to fix this problem ?**

OSSU is providing a learning opportunity for everyone who wants to learn Computer Science given that they've the time and effort required to pursue the studies [^1]. This means democratizing Computer Science education; make it accessible to everyone. Accessibility doesn't mean only providing the required material (i.e. courses) for free, but also providing the road-map and guidance on certain issues that the beginner learner doesn't have the experience to know or consider. And this is what OSSU is achieving by providing the courses, the road-map and the mentoring in the form of detailed guidance [^2]. 

Computer Science as a discipline is a branch of mathematics. Most universities around the world assume that students who aim at studying Computer Science have finished high school Mathematics. The way mathematics is taught in high school is not the best way to teach it. In fact, i don't think that anyone knows what is the best way to teach it. Nonetheless it remains a fact that many students who hate mathematics - because of a bad teacher, or the subject is presented in a way that doesn't reflect the true nature of Mathematics - are not in fact bad at Mathematics. This means that if the way Mathematics is presented in high schools changed, many'll find it an appealing and natural subject to learn [^3]; they'll become good at it. Changing the way Mathematics is presented in High Schools means introducing Mathematics when needed, not as a bunch of facts and techniques that the student should master; but as a tool for interpreting, solving, and expressing problems. In short, introduce Mathematics in relation to some problem, in the light of, or in context of something related to the field you study - which is CS in our case.

Given the above, and given the good intention of OSSU creators to advance humanity by making Computer Science learning accessible to a greater number of people who're willing to put their time and effort to become Computer Scientists, I claim that there is an opportunity for OSSU to fix a problem related to teaching mathematics in formal education, and hence make the curriculum accessible to a greater number of people, some of which can become good at CS and Math but discouraged by the mathematics - the problem of teaching math as a bunch of facts or techniques produced by some people (i.e. mathematicians) that the students ought to master - by introducing math lately in the curriculum. 

**How this proposed solution will contribute to fixing the math teaching problem in formal education ?**

By the time the learner finish "Intro CS" they would've been introduced to some mathematical concepts but in a superficial way. They'd also have an answer to the question: Is CS my field of interest or not. This is in fact the function of an Intro Course; to give the learner enough knowledge in order to decide if they would like to purse more or that what they've known is enough.

From the three courses in "Intro cs" -  CS50P, Python for Everybody, 6.0001 Introduction to Computer Science and Programming in Python - 6.0001 is the only course that introduce mathematical concepts because it's the only course that introduces CS. The other two courses are programming and not CS courses. 

For instance, in 6.0001 the first appearance of mathematical concept is in "Lec-3" the cubic root of some number and the "guess and check method"; The second appearance in "Lec-10,11" in the form of graphs of the running time of algorithms - constant, linear, log, ...etc. None of these require a whole knowledge and mastering of High School Math; they just need a simple search on google to understand what it means by cubic root. In terms of the graphs, the function of graphs in Mathematics in general is to express some Mathematical ideas visually. So, by only looking to the graphs the learner could see what constant mean visually and so on, also something that doesn't require mastering High School Math.

MIT, the university that is issuing the course is an engineering university. In fact the Bachelor Degree of Computer Science at MIT is a Degree in Computer Science and Engineering [^4]. Hence, MIT assumes that their freshman students should have High School knowledge not only of math but of physics also. This is one of the reasons of why MIT is known for its hard admission exams and the way they filter their freshmen students.

Every higher education institution has a way to filter students through entrance examinations - SAT, MCAT, ...etc. The reason that this is the case in higher education is because every college and university have a finite number of places for students - a situation which online MOOC education doesn't face - and the growth in higher education made an intense competition for seats [^5]. Therefore, filtering out students doesn't have any meaning in MOOC settings. In fact the opposite is true. MOOC is intended to everyone that is willing to invest their effort and time regardless of their background. Even if they didn't attend High School all together.

6.0001 Course itself - Not MIT, The University - doesn't require High School math as a prerequisite [^6]. The text-book recommended by the course itself is a book by Professor John Guttag, in the preface of the book there is no mentions to any prerequisite. In fact Professor John said "The book is aimed at 1) readers with little or no prior programming experience who have a desire to understand computational approaches to problem solving, and 2) more experienced programmers who want to learn how to use computation to model things or explore data." This second target audience of the book "The experienced programmers" are required to know, in Prof. John words "[what is required is] no knowledge of mathematics beyond high school algebra, but do assume that the reader is comfortable with rigorous thinking and is not intimidated by mathematical concepts." This requirement is needed for "experienced programmers" taking a second course in computer science, which is 6.0002, a course not in OSSU curriculum, and is not an introductory course. Professor John's book contains the material for teaching 6.0001 & 6.0002 [^7].  MIT in another place recommended prerequisite for this course 6.0001, which is in their words "No prior programming experience is necessary to take, understand, or be successful in 6.0001. Familiarity with pre-calculus, especially series, will be helpful for some topics, but is not required to understand the majority of the content. [^8]" The keywords here is "Some Topics" and "Is not required to understand the majority of the content". Does this means that MIT recommended pre-calculus and hence High School math as prerequisite for 6.0001 ? Yes. Does this mean that their is no other way to learn 6.0001 than learning the entirety of High School math ? No, because MIT themselves put this phrase "Is not required to understand the majority of the content" for a reason, to say, don't get discouraged to take this course if you don't have pre-calculus and hence High School math because "[its] not required to understand the majority of content". Is it then necessary to not take 6.0001 course until finishing High School Mathematics ? My answer is no. You can take the course and google the two concepts that will meet you.


**What can be modified in the current OSSU Curriculum ?**

I propose to move Mathematics Prerequisite to later in the Curriculum, to either directly before Core Programming, or to Directly before Core Mathematics. None of the Core Programming courses in fact require any Mathematics as a prerequisite. And prerequisites on Courcera, and in every other online learning platform or course, has to be said explicitly. 

In fact the reason to take High School mathematics is because it's a prerequisite for calculus. But than we must ask why we learn calculus in Computer Science, or at least why before Discrete Math ? Some would answer, because Calculus is a prerequisite for Discrete Math. This is what MIT recommended, but again, MIT is engineering university with an intense competition for the number of students allowed to study at MIT. 

This whole organization of Mathematics Curriculum in USA, and by implication in most of the world is questionable. Arithmetic, then Geometry, then Pre-Algebra, then High School Math (Pre-calculus), then calculus and discrete mathematics, is not the only why to learn mathematics; most of the people can learn Mathematics to even Higher Mathematics (Graduate level Mathematics) starting from Discrete Math or what we call "Math for Computer Science"[^9]. However, this argument is not the scope of this discussion. I just put it forward for the sake of showing that what we take for granted about learning math is not necessary the best way to learn it. this is not my personal opinion, this is the opinion of many great mathematician, for instance, George Pólya, and The Mathematician and Philosopher, Imre Lakatos ([^3] for more details).

**Final Words**

I'll Finish with a quote from the philosopher, educator, encyclopedist, and popular author Mortimer J. Adler that i think is directed to anyone who is responsible for providing education for people especially MOOC education. 
"We are on record as holding that unlimited education opportunity-or, specking practically, education opportunity that is limited only by individual desire, ability, and need- is the most valuable service that society can provide for its members. That we don't know how to provide that kind of opportunity is no reason to give up the attempt.[^10]."

{'action': 'created', 'issue': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/ossu/computer-science/issues/1231', 'repository_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/ossu/computer-science', 'labels_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/ossu/computer-science/issues/1231/labels{/name}', 'comments_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/ossu/computer-science/issues/1231/comments', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/ossu/computer-science/issues/1231/events', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/ossu/computer-science/issues/1231', 'id': 2224794472, 'node_id': 'I_kwDOAShAGM6Em6to', 'number': 1231, 'title': 'A proposal to shift the High School Matheamtics to later in the Curriculum. ', 'user': {'login': 'BurzumBlack', 'id': 50082799, 'node_id': 'MDQ6VXNlcjUwMDgyNzk5', 'avatar_url': 'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/50082799?v=4', 'gravatar_id': '', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/users/BurzumBlack', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/BurzumBlack', 'followers_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/BurzumBlack/followers', 'following_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/BurzumBlack/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/BurzumBlack/gists{/gist_id}', 'starred_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/BurzumBlack/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'subscriptions_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/BurzumBlack/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/BurzumBlack/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/BurzumBlack/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/BurzumBlack/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/BurzumBlack/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'site_admin': False}, 'labels': [], 'state': 'open', 'locked': False, 'assignee': None, 'assignees': [], 'milestone': None, 'comments': 1, 'created_at': '2024-04-04T08:14:19Z', 'updated_at': '2024-04-04T10:33:22Z', 'closed_at': None, 'author_association': 'NONE', 'active_lock_reason': None, 'body': 'TLTR;

The creators of OSSU i hope that this request find you well.

**What is the problem of math education in general and how OSSU could contribute to fix this problem ?**

OSSU is providing a learning opportunity for everyone who wants to learn Computer Science given that they've the time and effort required to pursue the studies [^1]. This means democratizing Computer Science education; make it accessible to everyone. Accessibility doesn't mean only providing the required material (i.e. courses) for free, but also providing the road-map and guidance on certain issues that the beginner learner doesn't have the experience to know or consider. And this is what OSSU is achieving by providing the courses, the road-map and the mentoring in the form of detailed guidance [^2]. 

Computer Science as a discipline is a branch of mathematics. Most universities around the world assume that students who aim at studying Computer Science have finished high school Mathematics. The way mathematics is taught in high school is not the best way to teach it. In fact, i don't think that anyone knows what is the best way to teach it. Nonetheless it remains a fact that many students who hate mathematics - because of a bad teacher, or the subject is presented in a way that doesn't reflect the true nature of Mathematics - are not in fact bad at Mathematics. This means that if the way Mathematics is presented in high schools changed, many'll find it an appealing and natural subject to learn [^3]; they'll become good at it. Changing the way Mathematics is presented in High Schools means introducing Mathematics when needed, not as a bunch of facts and techniques that the student should master; but as a tool for interpreting, solving, and expressing problems. In short, introduce Mathematics in relation to some problem, in the light of, or in context of something related to the field you study - which is CS in our case.

Given the above, and given the good intention of OSSU creators to advance humanity by making Computer Science learning accessible to a greater number of people who're willing to put their time and effort to become Computer Scientists, I claim that there is an opportunity for OSSU to fix a problem related to teaching mathematics in formal education, and hence make the curriculum accessible to a greater number of people, some of which can become good at CS and Math but discouraged by the mathematics - the problem of teaching math as a bunch of facts or techniques produced by some people (i.e. mathematicians) that the students ought to master - by introducing math lately in the curriculum. 

**How this proposed solution will contribute to fixing the math teaching problem in formal education ?**

By the time the learner finish "Intro CS" they would've been introduced to some mathematical concepts but in a superficial way. They'd also have an answer to the question: Is CS my field of interest or not. This is in fact the function of an Intro Course; to give the learner enough knowledge in order to decide if they would like to purse more or that what they've known is enough.

From the three courses in "Intro cs" -  CS50P, Python for Everybody, 6.0001 Introduction to Computer Science and Programming in Python - 6.0001 is the only course that introduce mathematical concepts because it's the only course that introduces CS. The other two courses are programming and not CS courses. 

For instance, in 6.0001 the first appearance of mathematical concept is in "Lec-3" the cubic root of some number and the "guess and check method"; The second appearance in "Lec-10,11" in the form of graphs of the running time of algorithms - constant, linear, log, ...etc. None of these require a whole knowledge and mastering of High School Math; they just need a simple search on google to understand what it means by cubic root. In terms of the graphs, the function of graphs in Mathematics in general is to express some Mathematical ideas visually. So, by only looking to the graphs the learner could see what constant mean visually and so on, also something that doesn't require mastering High School Math.

MIT, the university that is issuing the course is an engineering university. In fact the Bachelor Degree of Computer Science at MIT is a Degree in Computer Science and Engineering [^4]. Hence, MIT assumes that their freshman students should have High School knowledge not only of math but of physics also. This is one of the reasons of why MIT is known for its hard admission exams and the way they filter their freshmen students.

Every higher education institution has a way to filter students through entrance examinations - SAT, MCAT, ...etc. The reason that this is the case in higher education is because every college and university have a finite number of places for students - a situation which online MOOC education doesn't face - and the growth in higher education made an intense competition for seats [^5]. Therefore, filtering out students doesn't have any meaning in MOOC settings. In fact the opposite is true. MOOC is intended to everyone that is willing to invest their effort and time regardless of their background. Even if they didn't attend High School all together.

6.0001 Course itself - Not MIT, The University - doesn't require High School math as a prerequisite [^6]. The text-book recommended by the course itself is a book by Professor John Guttag, in the preface of the book there is no mentions to any prerequisite. In fact Professor John said "The book is aimed at 1) readers with little or no prior programming experience who have a desire to understand computational approaches to problem solving, and 2) more experienced programmers who want to learn how to use computation to model things or explore data." This second target audience of the book "The experienced programmers" are required to know, in Prof. John words "[what is required is] no knowledge of mathematics beyond high school algebra, but do assume that the reader is comfortable with rigorous thinking and is not intimidated by mathematical concepts." This requirement is needed for "experienced programmers" taking a second course in computer science, which is 6.0002, a course not in OSSU curriculum, and is not an introductory course. Professor John's book contains the material for teaching 6.0001 & 6.0002 [^7].  MIT in another place recommended prerequisite for this course 6.0001, which is in their words "No prior programming experience is necessary to take, understand, or be successful in 6.0001. Familiarity with pre-calculus, especially series, will be helpful for some topics, but is not required to understand the majority of the content. [^8]" The keywords here is "Some Topics" and "Is not required to understand the majority of the content". Does this means that MIT recommended pre-calculus and hence High School math as prerequisite for 6.0001 ? Yes. Does this mean that their is no other way to learn 6.0001 than learning the entirety of High School math ? No, because MIT themselves put this phrase "Is not required to understand the majority of the content" for a reason, to say, don't get discouraged to take this course if you don't have pre-calculus and hence High School math because "[its] not required to understand the majority of content". Is it then necessary to not take 6.0001 course until finishing High School Mathematics ? My answer is no. You can take the course and google the two concepts that will meet you.


**What can be modified in the current OSSU Curriculum ?**

I propose to move Mathematics Prerequisite to later in the Curriculum, to either directly before Core Programming, or to Directly before Core Mathematics. None of the Core Programming courses in fact require any Mathematics as a prerequisite. And prerequisites on Courcera, and in every other online learning platform or course, has to be said explicitly. 

In fact the reason to take High School mathematics is because it's a prerequisite for calculus. But than we must ask why we learn calculus in Computer Science, or at least why before Discrete Math ? Some would answer, because Calculus is a prerequisite for Discrete Math. This is what MIT recommended, but again, MIT is engineering university with an intense competition for the number of students allowed to study at MIT. 

This whole organization of Mathematics Curriculum in USA, and by implication in most of the world is questionable. Arithmetic, then Geometry, then Pre-Algebra, then High School Math (Pre-calculus), then calculus and discrete mathematics, is not the only why to learn mathematics; most of the people can learn Mathematics to even Higher Mathematics (Graduate level Mathematics) starting from Discrete Math or what we call "Math for Computer Science"[^9]. However, this argument is not the scope of this discussion. I just put it forward for the sake of showing that what we take for granted about learning math is not necessary the best way to learn it. this is not my personal opinion, this is the opinion of many great mathematician, for instance, George Pólya, and The Mathematician and Philosopher, Imre Lakatos ([^3] for more details).

**Final Words**

I'll Finish with a quote from the philosopher, educator, encyclopedist, and popular author Mortimer J. Adler that i think is directed to anyone who is responsible for providing education for people especially MOOC education. 
"We are on record as holding that unlimited education opportunity-or, specking practically, education opportunity that is limited only by individual desire, ability, and need- is the most valuable service that society can provide for its members. That we don't know how to provide that kind of opportunity is no reason to give up the attempt.[^10]."

Because we think the course requires it. We have seen people who had not completed prerequisite math struggle in this course.

### But I have completed the course without prerequisite math?

Good for you. But the majority of people don't. Just saying that math is not required won't be a good thing to do.

### Why doesn't OSSU replace the course with something that does not require math?

That can happen. But OSSU emulates a typical CS degree. While MIT is not typical, high school math is required almost everywhere you can get a CS degree. So, it makes sense for OSSU to require high school math.

---

I think you are missing an important aspect of OSSU: ***OSSU emulates a typical CS degree***. A typical CS degree requires high school knowledge.

OSSU does not do research on what methodology of teaching is better and what concepts should be taught. OSSU just follows the [CS 2013 Curriculum Guidelines](https://www.acm.org/binaries/content/assets/education/cs2013_web_final.pdf).", 'reactions': {'url': 'https://api.github.com/repos/ossu/computer-science/issues/comments/2036803156/reactions', 'total_count': 0, '+1': 0, '-1': 0, 'laugh': 0, 'hooray': 0, 'confused': 0, 'heart': 0, 'rocket': 0, 'eyes': 0}, 'performed_via_github_app': None}}
